data.title: Problem with "Soft Wrap" when "Show Invisibles" is on
data.body:
### Description

Soft Wrapping ignores "Cr" and "Eol"  even when show invisibles are switched on.
This is especially evident when using Japanese. (The following Steps are examined in Japanese)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Make sure "Soft Wrap" and "Show Invisibles" are on from [Setting] -> [Editor]
2. Type in any Japanese Character such as "あ" repetitively until it reachs the second line. ( As soft wrap is on, the second line here means the first line with a "dot" as the line number) 
3. Move the cursor to the first letter in the second line and change lines there.

The problem occurs here. the Soft Wrap does not recognize the "Cr" and "Eol" and the line ends in the midst of the two invisibles and a scroll bar for sideways appear.
As a result, when you try to edit the end of the first line, the window moves sideways, causing a annoying shaking.

![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22351407/18748387/f15547c4-810c-11e6-957c-ec643d10bbb1.png)
### Versions

Atom 1.10.2 is running on Windows 10

I have tried this after turning all packages off and it still happened.

data.title: Always invalidate yardstick measurements when the editor becomes visible
data.body:
...because content could get reflowed and previous measurements might become inaccurate. Typically, this could occur when measuring while the editor is hidden: in that case, the yardstick would always report `0px` and save that position into the cache. Then, when the editor becomes visible again, the wrong `0px` value would be returned, thus causing cursors etc. to be displayed incorrectly.

This was being shadowed by a 🐛 in our measurements cache, but after fixing it in #12730 it started becoming more evident.

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Exclude VCS Ignored Paths unchecked not showing node_modules
data.body:
I'm using Atom version 1.10.2 on a Mac.

When I click on Atom > Preferences > Core and uncheck 'Exclude VCS Ignored Paths' I am still unable to see my node_modules directory. I've tried restarting Atom as well. 

Here is an Atom Discuss post on the subject, but the solution is not working for me: https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-do-i-open-node-modules-dir/23708

Hoping someone has had luck on resolving this.

data.title: Always return an empty array in TokenizedBuffer.getInvalidatedRanges
data.body:
Previously, we were always mistakenly returning `[(0, 0), (0, 0)]`, thus causing the first line of a file to be constantly invalidated. This caused also a performance regression for long lines with lots of highlight decorations at row 0, because any change in the buffer at other rows caused that line to be re-rendered and, therefore, re-measured as well. This was a contributing factor in the performance problem mentioned on #12662.

Since `TokenizedBuffer` never synchronously invalidates beyond the extent of the spatial change we can simply return an empty array instead.

data.title: editor:delete-line should preserve line position
data.body:
### Description

The command `editor:delete-line` should preserve current cursor position after removing line.
### Steps to Reproduce

For example we have file `data.js`:

``` javascript
var arr = [
        'main',
        'user',
        'settings',
        'lang',
        'billing',
];
```
1. Put cursor in file at line `settings` after first quote.
2. Call delete-line command

**Expected behavior:** Cursor is at the `lang` line after first quote. Line position is 9.

**Actual behavior:** Cursor is at the start of  `lang` line. Line position is 0.
### Versions

Atom 1.10.2, macOS 10.10

data.title: Move Line breaks indentation in python
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Moving lines or blocks of text around with Move Line Up/Down (CTRL+Up/Down) in python messes with the indentation. The code block gets indented to match the indentation of the block just above, assuming you want to nest it there. In general this results in code you have to re-indent back after moving. 

![optimised](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1453692/18712371/6b316ce4-800e-11e6-9e52-aaeee5845d1f.gif)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. In a python script, select a line or block of text. 
2. Move it around with CTRL+Up/Down so it is below an indented line, e.g. a function. 

**Expected behavior:** The block of text is moved with its indentation preserved

**Actual behavior:** The indentation matches that of the line just above. 
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

❋ ~ ❯ atom --version
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
❋ ~ ❯ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1
❋ ~ ❯ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS
Release:    14.04
Codename:   trusty

data.title: Installing Atom on Raspberry PI 3
data.body:
I have used the following commands to try to install Atom on a Raspberry PI
git clone https://github.com/atom/atom.git
cd atom
Get npm setup 
sudo npm install node-gyp
sudo npm config set python /usr/bin/python2
Build and install Atom
sudo ./script/build  -–create-debian-package
cd out
sudo dpkg add-architecture arm
sudo dpkg –i atom-arm-deb
sudo apt-get –f install

I have had a number of errors in the process but finally got to the end without any errors.  I can see the installation but it does not run.  

When I try to run from the menu I get a spinning wheel and then no output.

Trying to run from the command line I get
nohup: failed to run command 'tmp/atom-build/Atom.atom': No such file or directory

I am assuming that Atom currently does not support running under a Raspberry PI architecture.

data.title: Return the last active tab when close a tab
data.body: For example, open a project-wide search tab by `ctrl-shift-f` then close it, it should returns to the last _used_ tab in MRU order, but current version it returns to last tab in display order.

data.title: Fix for broken link in the contributing document
data.body: I was checking out the contributing document and noticed the JS style guide link is dead. I figured the second best thing would be the JS styleguide in the document itself?

data.title: Add atom.restartApplication
data.body: This uses the new Electron `app.relaunch` API and will be used to restart Atom after updating packages or when changing the `useCustomTitleBar` option. Restart is actually performed in the main process in `AtomApplication.restart`, and we preserve various command line flags from the previous instance based on the state of the application.

data.title: Setting Default Syntax for New Documents
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [Y] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [Y] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [Y] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [Y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [Y] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [Y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Opening a new document defaults to "Plain Text" syntax. You can save the file with a select file extension or manually select a syntax but cannot set the default syntax for new documents. An official init.coffee solution exists on the [Atom FAQ](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-can-i-make-all-new-files-open-with-a-specific-grammar-or-syntax/20754) however new documents still default to "Plain Text" and rather only opening a new tab defaults to the desired syntax:

```
atom.workspace.observeTextEditors (editor) ->
  if editor.getTitle() is "untitled"
    editor.setGrammar(atom.grammars.grammarForScopeName('text.html.php'))
```

Other developers have noted the bug appears to be, "Open Empty Editor On Start option enabled is required as this issue only occurs on the first editor created by that option."
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Edit init.coffee with above code
2. Restart Atom
3. Open Atom and notice default syntax is still Plain Text

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Default syntax (based on above code) should be PHP
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
It is still Plain Text (unless you open another tab via shortcut or Menu). Opening New Window view menu or shortcut also results in same issue.
### Versions

1.10.2, Mac 10.12 (16A313a)

data.title: Don't remeasure the first character of a line
data.body:
Previously we were ignoring the measurement cache for characters located at `left: 0px` because `0` is evaluated as falsy in Javascript, causing those character to be constantly re-measured.

This pull-request fixes it so that we explicitly check for null values when consulting the cache. It's pretty minor, but should save some CPU cycles when rendering an editor.

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Keybinding shortcut with escape character
data.body:
The problem is, that when I try to override the Core-Shortcut 'alt-\' it won't work inside the keymap.cson file because \' is an escape character and I can't leave it like that. I can't write a backslash anymore because the key binding. I already tried:
'alt-\' : 'unset!'
'alt-\ ' : 'unset!'
'alt-\'' : 'unset!:
nothing of these keybindings worked or disabled the core keybinding.

data.title: Clicking Atom's dock icon isn't opening new windows
data.body:
### Description

Clicking Atom's dock icon isn't opening new windows.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom.app.
2. Close the Window from the red traffic light button (top left of window).
3. Click still running Atom.app icon from the Dock.

**Expected behavior:**

A new empty window to open.

**Actual behavior:**

Nothing happens.
### Versions

macOS 10.11.6.
Atom built from source at 2ed2121e4baed2643aabf6ec9da6e96b97c18762.
